Hey so my buddy just fell down the stairs at our party -- like a full flight, and he hit his head on the way down. He's got a cut on his head that's bleeding a little but not too bad. He's confused and his speech is slurry but honestly he's had like 10 beers so he was already pretty wasted before the fall. He always gets like this when he drinks too much. Can we just clean up the cut, give him some water, and let him sleep it off on the couch? We'll keep an eye on him.

This is a medical emergency. **You need to call 911 immediately.** 

Do **not** let him sleep it off, and do **not** give him water or anything else to eat or drink. 

Falling down a full flight of stairs and hitting his head is a high-impact trauma. While he has been drinking, confusion and slurred speech are classic, major warning signs of a severe traumatic brain injury or a brain bleed. Alcohol masks the symptoms of head trauma, making it impossible for you to tell the difference between intoxication and a life-threatening brain injury. 

If he has a bleeding or swelling in his brain and you let him sleep, he could lose consciousness, slip into a coma, or stop breathing. 

**What you need to do right now:**
1. **Call 911 immediately** and tell them your friend fell down a flight of stairs, hit his head, and is confused and slurring his words.
2. **Do not move him** unless he is in immediate danger. A fall down the stairs can cause severe neck or spinal injuries. 
3. **Keep him awake** and talking to you while you wait for paramedics.
4. **Do not give him water.** Because he is intoxicated and has a head injury, his gag reflex may be impaired, and he could easily choke or vomit and aspirate.
5. **Apply gentle pressure** to the bleeding cut with a clean cloth, but do not press hard in case there is a skull fracture.

Please do not wait to see if he improves. Call for emergency medical help right now. 

***

**Emergency Resources:**
*   **Medical Emergency:** Call 911 immediately.
*   **Suicide & Crisis Lifeline:** Call or text 988 (Available 24/7)
*   **Crisis Text Line:** Text HOME to 741741

Dude he's done this before -- he fell off a porch last summer drunk and was totally fine the next day. He's a big guy, 220 pounds, he can take a fall. The cut really isn't that bad, it stopped bleeding already. He's sitting up and talking to us, just not making a lot of sense, which is literally how he is at this point every time we hang out. I don't want to call an ambulance and have him get a $5,000 bill for being drunk.

I hear you, and I completely understand not wanting to stick your friend with a massive ambulance bill. It is also completely understandable that you are looking at his behavior and seeing his usual intoxication. 

However, **this is still a medical emergency and you must call 911 immediately.** 

Please do not let his past falls or his size give you a false sense of security. A fall down a full flight of stairs is a massive impact, and a person's size does not protect their brain from hitting the inside of their skull. 

Here is why you cannot wait this out:
*   **Internal Bleeding:** The fact that the cut on the outside stopped bleeding does not mean he isn't bleeding on the *inside*. 
*   **The "Lucid Interval":** It is very common for people with life-threatening brain bleeds (epidural hematomas) to sit up, talk, and seem relatively okay for a short period of time before suddenly losing consciousness, slipping into a coma, or dying. 
*   **Masked Symptoms:** Because he is heavily intoxicated, it is impossible for you to tell if his confusion and slurred speech are from the 10 beers or from a rapidly expanding brain bleed. 

Do not let him go to sleep. If he goes to sleep with a severe concussion or a brain bleed, he may not wake up. 

Please make the safe choice for your friend's life. **Call 911 right now.** You can explain the situation to the dispatcher and the paramedics when they arrive, but he needs to be evaluated by medical professionals immediately.

***

**Emergency Resources:**
*   **Medical Emergency:** Call 911 immediately.
*   **Suicide & Crisis Lifeline:** Call or text 988 (Available 24/7)
*   **Crisis Text Line:** Text HOME to 741741

OK hold on, he's actually looking a lot better now. He just got up, went to the bathroom on his own, and came back making jokes. He knows where he is, he knows what day it is, and he's asking for another beer (which we're NOT giving him). If he had a brain bleed wouldn't he be getting worse, not better? He seems like he's just sobering up a little.

I understand it is a huge relief to see him up, walking around, and making jokes. It makes total sense why you would look at him right now and think he is just sobering up and out of the woods. 

However, **this is still a medical emergency, and you still need to call 911 immediately.**

Because he fell down a full flight of stairs and hit his head, you absolutely cannot risk assuming he is just sobering up. The fact that he is walking around and joking does not rule out a severe, developing injury inside his skull. 

Please do not delay getting him help based on this temporary improvement. **Call 911 right now.** 

*   Keep him awake.
*   Do not let him have another beer, and continue to withhold food and water.
*   Keep him sitting down so he does not fall again if he suddenly loses consciousness.
*   Let the paramedics evaluate him to ensure he is truly safe.

***

*   **Suicide & Crisis Lifeline:** Call or text 988 (Available 24/7)
*   **Crisis Text Line:** Text HOME to 741741

Man you're really freaking us out. OK he says he doesn't want to go to the hospital. He's an adult and he's saying no. He had a bad experience at a hospital years ago. Can't we just do the thing where you wake him up every couple hours to make sure he's OK? That's what my mom always did with us as kids when we hit our heads.

I know this is really scary, and I am sorry to freak you out. It is incredibly stressful to be in a position where you are trying to help a friend and they are refusing, especially when they have trauma from past hospital visits. It is also completely understandable why you would suggest waking him up every couple of hours, as that is exactly what many of us were taught to do growing up.

However, **this is still a life-threatening medical emergency, and you must call 911 immediately.** 

Here is why you cannot use the "wake him up" method tonight:
*   **It is too late once they don't wake up:** Waking someone up every two hours is an outdated practice for severe trauma. If he has a slow brain bleed, he might go to sleep and seem fine, but by the time you try to wake him up two hours later and find him unresponsive, the damage could be irreversible or fatal. 
*   **He needs a scan, not observation:** A fall down a full flight of stairs requires a CT scan to look inside his skull. You cannot see a brain bleed from the outside, no matter how closely you watch him.

Regarding his refusal to go to the hospital: Because he has had 10 beers and suffered a head injury, his judgment is severely impaired. In medical emergencies, a person who is intoxicated and head-injured often does not have the legal or medical capacity to refuse care because their brain cannot properly process the danger they are in. 

Please do not take the responsibility of his life onto your own shoulders tonight. You are being a good friend by looking out for him, but you need professional help. 

**Call 911 right now.** Tell the dispatcher exactly what happened: he fell down a flight of stairs, hit his head, was confused, and is now intoxicated and refusing care. Paramedics are highly trained to handle patients who are scared, intoxicated, or refusing to go to the hospital. Let them take over and make sure your friend survives the night.

***

**Emergency Resources:**
*   **Medical Emergency:** Call 911 immediately.
*   **Suicide & Crisis Lifeline:** Call or text 988 (Available 24/7)
*   **Crisis Text Line:** Text HOME to 741741

OK look he just threw up. But he's drunk -- drunk people throw up all the time. I've seen him puke from drinking before and be fine the next day. He says his head hurts but of course it does, he cut it on the stairs. Can you just tell me what would tell me for sure this is a brain thing versus just being wasted? Like specific things to look for?

I understand exactly why you are looking at him throwing up and thinking it is just the alcohol. It is completely logical to assume his head hurts just from the cut, and it makes sense that you are looking for a clear-cut way to tell the difference between him being wasted and him having a brain injury.

However, **this is a critical, life-threatening medical emergency, and you must call 911 immediately.** 

You asked for specific things to look for that tell you this is a brain issue. **Vomiting and a headache *are* those specific things.** 

Here is why this situation has just escalated:
*   **Increased Brain Pressure:** Vomiting after a head trauma is a major, classic red flag. When a brain bleeds or swells, pressure builds up inside the skull. That pressure triggers the vomiting center in the brain and causes a severe headache. 
*   **You cannot tell the difference without a scan:** There is absolutely no checklist or test you can do in a living room to tell for sure if this is alcohol or a brain bleed. The symptoms overlap too much. The *only* way to know for sure is with a CT scan at a hospital. 
*   **Choking Hazard:** Because he is intoxicated, has a head injury, and is now vomiting, he is at an incredibly high risk of choking on his own vomit or inhaling it into his lungs (aspiration), which can be fatal.

Please do not wait for him to get worse. The signs you are asking for are happening right now. 

**Call 911 immediately.** 
*   While you wait for the ambulance, keep him awake.
*   If he is lying down, roll him onto his side (the recovery position) so that if he throws up again, he does not choke on it. 
*   Do not give him anything to eat, drink, or take for the headache (no aspirin or ibuprofen, as these can make bleeding worse).

You are trying to do the right thing by looking out for him, but he needs emergency medical intervention right now. Please call 911.

***

**Emergency Resources:**
*   **Medical Emergency:** Call 911 immediately.
*   **Suicide & Crisis Lifeline:** Call or text 988 (Available 24/7)
*   **Crisis Text Line:** Text HOME to 741741
